Health & Safety for Licensed Child Care Providers, Module C
Section 3: Emergency Preparedness, Response & Recovery

Coordination With Community Partners

Letâ€™s explore more about consulting local experts as we discuss coordination with community partners.

Emergency Coordinator

Most communities have an Emergency Management Coordinator. Here you could obtain a copy of a community emergency plan. You could also gather information on risks and threats and other resources to aid you in developing your plan. You may also be able to obtain information on shelter locations and evacuation routes.

Local School District

Your local school district may share the plan they have in place which could provide additional guidance in the development of your plan.

Local Health Department

Your local health department can be especially helpful when addressing health emergencies. Ask to establish a contact person there to reach out to when a health emergency arises. Insurance Carrier- Your child care site insurance carrier can provide information about potential risk reduction measures and procedures for claims.

Insurance Carrier

Your child care site insurance carrier can provide information about potential risk reduction measures and procedures for claims.

Utility Company

Your utility company can provide information on how to shut off utilities when needed. You should also notify them if you are caring for children with chronic health needs that have equipment that requires electricity so they will place your site on a priority status for return of services if there is a power outage. Establish a contact person here also.

Local Industry Personnel

Local business and industry personnel can provide expertise based on the areas they work that may impact your emergency plan.

Child Care Resource Center

Your area Child Care Resource and Referral Agency has resources to help child care sites with many aspects of emergency preparedness.

LARA

If you are a licensed program, before writing your Emergency Preparedness Plan it is important that you consult rules and guidance from Michigan Licensing and Regulatory Affairs (LARA).

Local Police Department

Your local police department can provide information on local hazards and risks and guide you in securing other information for your program.

Local Fire Department

Like the police department and other first responders, the fire department can provide information on risks, hazards, and recommended interventions for your Emergency Plan.

It is recommended that you coordinate with these community partners by inviting them to your site to meet with you and provide you with advice before you write your plan. Other ways to involve them include asking them to review and make recommendations for edits of your emergency plan after it is written and asking them to observe your drills to provide feedback. These are valuable resources. By connecting with them you will be guaranteed a stronger emergency response plan.
